awd_titl_txt: MATH: EAGER: Developing a Learning Map for Introductory Statistics
awd_abstract_narration:
The overall goal of this project will be to create and validate a "learning map" (Stat-LM) for the content of undergraduate introductory statistics. This learning map will be a graphical representation of statistics concepts with connections among the concepts suggesting effective learning sequences. Use of the learning map will improve undergraduate learning by providing diagnostic information to instructors about students in their statistics courses, informing professional development for undergraduate statistics instructors, and modeling how critical prerequisites taught in high school connect to postsecondary learning expectations. In the first phase of the project, researchers will collaborate with statistics instructors from five institutions to create a learning map representing the broadest possible content set for introductory statistics material and the typical learning patterns of students in statistics courses taught in high school, community college, and university settings. In the second phase of the project, the research team will study the accuracy of the learning map using data collected from the Comprehensive Assessment of Outcomes in a First Statistics Course (CAOS), a confirmed valid and reliable assessment of student learning in statistics. This analysis will provide evidence of the learning map"s accuracy as a model of how students develop knowledge of introductory statistics. 

The project will build on research conducted at the University of Kansas in the development and application of learning maps as tools to support instruction and assessment by addressing two specific aims. First, the Stat-LM will be developed by expert statistics educators, educational psychologists, and statistics instructors from five varied types of institutions to model the broadest possible set of topics taught at the university level, thereby assuring its relevance for high school and undergraduate courses. Expert reviewers will provide feedback on the nodes and connections in the map in order to refine the content validity of the Stat-LM as a model of student learning. Second, the analysis using quantitative data collected from the CAOS will consist of an alignment study of the test items on the CAOS to the Stat-LM, identifying the nodes in the Stat-LM that students must have mastered to answer each item correctly. Along with data from the CAOS found to be aligned to the map, the map specification will be analyzed with diagnostic classification (also called Bayesian network methods; e.g., Rupp, Templin, & Henson, 2010). Based on results from these analyses, the researchers will evaluate the Stat-LM with respect to the ordered connections between nodes and the validity of nodes themselves as latent constructs. The Stat-LM will become a "living document", subject to refinements throughout the proposed project and thereafter. As the goal of this project is to produce a tool for aiding statistics instruction, versions of the Stat-LM will be shared broadly for use within varied instructional settings.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on developing a learning map for a subset of the content taught in Introductory college statistics courses. Such a learning map can inform effective instruction by defining and describing the content domain at a particulate level and proposing directed connections among the skills to suggest productive learning sequences. The outcomes together suggest that this work is useful for educators and researchers as they deepen their understanding of how students learn particular content.

Outcome 1: A team of four statistics educators developed a learning map model containing over 300 skills to propose a theory of learning of statistics topics related to univariate, quantitative data. The resulting map provides accurate descriptions of skills and theoretical pathways among the skills to indicate productive learning sequences

Outcome 2: The team developed 95 new statistics test items aligned to the learning map model. The items were developed, piloted, and validated using test development best practices.

 Outcome 3: Test items were administered to a national sample of college students (n > 1000) enrolled in introductory statistics courses. Data from the assessments were analyzed to examine how well the learning map model matched actual student test responses. Analyses revealed:

  • The concepts and skills in the map appeared to be well defined according to the parameters computed during analysis. This finding is important because many clusters of the skills and concepts we defined are often taught/learned/assessed altogether and not necessarily distinguished within instruction or assessments. The analyses from this project indicated that the skills and concepts in the learning map model were well defined (i.e., unique), which suggests that students may need specific instruction to target each of these small grain-size skills instead of or in addition to cluster level instruction. Therefore, instructors and students may benefit from being aware of the sub-skills and how they comprise knowledge and understanding of the cluster of skills to which they belong.
  • The sample size of roughly 1000 responses to 4 items per skill was too small to verify proposed connections among skills. This is helpful to the field, but it confirms that verifying complex, networked learning models remains difficult because obtaining large samples of students tested on the same connected skills with sufficient numbers of items is not practical in most learning environments. This problem requires more study.

Outcome 4: The team reported this work to have several professional benefits:

  • Collaborative study of the literature on student learning of introductory statistics strengthened team members’ domain knowledge and instructional preparation.
  • Knowledge and development of organized learning models, i.e., learning map models, assisted instructors in refining lessons, lesson sequences, and courses.
  • Knowledge and practice of test item and test form development improved instructors’ capacity to author high-quality instructional tasks and assessments.
